Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project Grant: Smart Grid Simulator Development for Multidisciplinary Teaching and Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project at Prairie View A&M University is developing a smart grid simulator. The project aims to achieve the following objectives: (a) revamp multidisciplinary lectures and corresponding labs in the context of smart grids; (b) improve student learning in power and energy areas; (c) promote multidisciplinary research collaborations on smart grids; (d) develop faculty expertise through research and teaching initiatives; and (e) disseminate results and findings for the academic community and the general public. The project will directly impact 390 undergraduate students, most of whom are from underrepresented groups, in the departments of electrical and computer engineering and engineering technology.

The smart grid simulator will integrate simulation software, power electronic devices, motors, embedded microprocessors, and cybernetics to construct a simulated environment with hardware-in-the-loop. A collaborative consortium allows for the most qualified research expertise to tackle the grand challenges in smart grid education and research. Centered on the power grid simulator, segmented resources in several teaching laboratories are infused, and traditional power engineering education is enriched with complementary courses to strengthen student knowledge and skills in communication and information technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The electric power grid evolved over a century in a largely regulated context and tightly integrating network. With technology progress, the existing power grid centralized, producer controlled generation and uni-directional transmission and distribution network will gradually shift to distributed generation with significant integration of renewable energy and bi-directional power flow. To strengthen the education in power area to meet the rising demand for grid modernization and workforce replacement, the project is to develop a smart grid simulator to benefit multidisciplinary education and research.

1. Intellectual Merit: (a) Smart grid simulation platform has been established, including three distributed nodes to represent generator, load and power grid. The distributed nodes are connected through real-time communication to achieve the interaction among nodes to demonstrate load variation and generation adjustment. (b) This project promoted multidisciplinary research collaborations among three PIs in power system, control theory and communication. The collaborated to supervise graduate students and publish papers. (c) Curriculum and laboratory development were propelled with this NSF project. PI developed three core courses (power system, power electronics, electric machine) in his home department. (d) Leveraging on this project, PIs received several external grants including one multi-million research center project funded by DoD.

2. Broad impact: (i) Pioneering research results were published in journal and conferences, including one paper received best paper award nomination certificate. (ii) Several graduate and undergraduate students worked in this project to assist PIs to develop new courseware, assist undergraduate lab course, and perform researches in power area. Several of them are now working in power related companies after graduation. (iii) Faculty workshop was organized to disseminate results and establish connections with neighboring institutions. (iv) Leveraging on the faculty workshop, Engineering Technology Forum was initiated and organized to discuss sustainable development of Engineering Technology and facilitate the transfer pathway for community college students. (v) PIs attended various conferences, workshops and seminars to give talks, present papers, and network with peers in the academic community.
